abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Bahia Poor Urban Areas
            Integrated Development Project for Brazil were as follows:
            outcomes were moderately unsatisfactory, risk to development
            outcome was substantial, Bank performance was moderately
            unsatisfactory, and Borrower performance was moderately
            unsatisfactory. Some lessons learned included: an investment
            loan dealing with slum upgrading should have an integrated
            approach to social and physical urban interventions.
            Assessing the importance of achieving gradual and small
            scale improvements (such as providing new homes, improving
            sanitation coverage, or increasing access to educational
            facilities) can help in setting expectations for the project
            as a whole, and later in assessing the project's impact
            and its contribution to sustainable poverty reduction in a
            targeted area. It is important to size the right project for
            the right level of administration. Project preparation of an
            investment loan should strike the right balance between
            readiness to implement and flexibility in project design.
            Bank engagement in urban and slum upgrading projects should
            include work on housing policy and finance at local level.
            Teams dealing with projects targeting at-risk and vulnerable
            areas should carefully consider variables that may be
            difficult to control. Sequencing in core activities linked
            to slum upgrading projects can be the key to a successful
            project implementation. Bank fiduciary approaches to project
            supervision can be better integrated, harmonized, and
            congruent to clients' capacities, in order to reduce
            project management costs and facilitate day to day routine
            supervision and implementation.
